papers.abstract: Youth regularly use technology driven by artificial intelligence (AI). However, it is increasingly well-known that AI can cause harm on small and large scales, especially for those underrepresented in tech fields. Recently, users have played active roles in surfacing and mitigating harm from algorithmic bias. Despite being frequent users of AI, youth have been under-explored as potential contributors and stakeholders to the future of AI. We consider three notions that may be at the root of youth facing barriers to playing an active role in responsible AI, which are youth (1) cannot understand the technical aspects of AI, (2) cannot understand the ethical issues around AI, and (3) need protection from serious topics related to bias and injustice. In this study, we worked with youth (N = 30) in first through twelfth grade and parents (N = 6) to explore how youth can be part of identifying algorithmic bias and designing future systems to address problematic technology behavior. We found that youth are capable of identifying and articulating algorithmic bias, often in great detail. Participants suggested different ways users could give feedback for AI that reflects their values of diversity and inclusion. Youth who may have less experience with computing or exposure to societal structures can be supported by peers or adults with more of this knowledge, leading to critical conversations about fairer AI. This work illustrates youths' insights, suggesting that they should be integrated in building a future of responsible AI.

Recently, users have played active roles in surfacing and mitigating harm from algorithmic bias. Youth have been under-explored as potential contributors and stakeholders to the future of AI.

events.Text: We consider three notions that may be at the root of youth facing barriers to playing an active role in responsible AI, which are youth (1) cannot understand the technical aspects of AI, (2) cannot understand the ethical issues around AI, and (3) need protection from serious topics related to bias and injustice. In this study, we worked with youth (N = 30) in first through twelfth grade and parents (N = 6) to explore how youth can be part of identifying algorithmic bias and designing future systems to address problematic technology behavior.

Primary Object: how youth can participate in identifying algorithmic bias
designing future systems to address problematic technology behavior
Secondary Object: barriers to youth engaging proactively in responsible AI

Context: three notions that may impede youth from playing active roles in responsible AI
youth cannot understand technical aspects of AI
cannot grasp ethical issues surrounding AI
require protection from topics concerning bias and injustice
Purpose: explore how youth can be part of identifying algorithmic bias
designing future systems to address problematic technology behavior
Results: gained understanding of youth perspectives on AI issues
insights into parent involvement in supporting youth
Analysis: why some factors hinder youth participation
strategies to encourage overcoming these barriers
Challenge: managing diverse viewpoints in collaborative settings
Ethical: fostering trust and transparency in AI technologies
aligning with ethical standards promoting responsible AI
Implications: interventions to enhance youth engagement in AI
contributions toward global responsible AI initiatives

events.Text: We found that youth are capable of identifying and articulating algorithmic bias, often in great detail. Participants suggested different ways users could give feedback for AI that reflects their values of diversity and inclusion. Youth who may have less experience with computing or exposure to societal structures can be supported by peers or adults with more of this knowledge, leading to critical conversations about fairer AI.
This work illustrates youths' insights, suggesting that they should be integrated in building a future of responsible AI.

papers.abstract: The global population of refugees as recorded by UNHCR is at an all-time high of over 90 million people forced to find new homes in a foreign land. Starting a new life can be unsettling for refugees and asylum seekers during the resettling process in their host countries, particularly when it comes to gaining financial independence. This paper used an interview-based study to engage with fifteen refugees and asylum seekers to learn how they achieve entrepreneurial success as they navigate refugee specific barriers in a new economy. The insights showed refugee entrepreneur specific barriers that align with resettlement challenges and the technical and social resourcefulness of this under-resourced community. Our contributions to the CSCW research community are an understanding of how low-socioeconomic entrepreneurs such as refugees, function in their ecosystem and design implications for developing technology to further the efforts of refugee entrepreneurs.

events.Text: The global population of refugees as recorded by UNHCR is at an all-time high of over 90 million people forced to find new homes in a foreign land. Starting a new life can be unsettling for refugees and asylum seekers during the resettling process in their host countries, particularly when it comes to gaining financial independence.

Context: Global Population of Refugees as Recorded by UNHCR
UNHCR Data Showing Over 90 Million People Forced to Seek New Homes
Uncertainty Surrounding Mental and Economic Adaptations
Purpose: Address Difficulties Faced During Resettlement Processes
Method: Empirical Analysis Using Datasets Collected Globally
Results: Increased Awareness Among Policymakers About Complexities
Potential Leads to Better Preparedness Measures
Enhanced Community Support Structures Tailored to Needs Post-Settlement
Analysis: Improving Future Studies Through Enhanced Data Collection
Challenge: Gathering Comprehensive Enough Data Sets Representing Diverse Regional Conditions
Ensuring Accuracy of Measurements Including Variables Like Adaptation Rates
Ethical: Informed Consent When Collecting Personal Data Linked to Refugees
Implications: Long-Term Societal Benefits From Improved Refugee Integration Practices

events.Text: This paper used an interview-based study to engage with fifteen refugees and asylum seekers to learn how they achieve entrepreneurial success as they navigate refugee specific barriers in a new economy.

Secondary Object: Refugee-specific barriers in a new economy

Context: To understand how refugees achieve entrepreneurial success while facing specific challenges
Purpose: Explore how refugees overcome barriers to achieve entrepreneurial success in a new economy

events.Text: The insights showed refugee entrepreneur specific barriers that align with resettlement challenges and the technical and social resourcefulness of this under-resourced community.

Purpose: To investigate the barriers faced by refugee entrepreneurs during resettlement
Method: Qualitative interviews with 15 participants and thematic analysis
Results: Refugee entrepreneurs face specific barriers aligned with resettlement challenges
Analysis: These barriers relate to both technical skills and social integration difficulties
Challenge: Under-resourcing limits access to resources required for successful integration
Ethical: Potential ethical concerns arise from limited support systems affecting vulnerable populations
Implications: Understanding these barriers can inform policy interventions aimed at improving integration success

events.Text: Our contributions to the CSCW research community are an understanding of how low-socioeconomic entrepreneurs such as refugees, function in their ecosystem and design implications for developing technology to further the efforts of refugee entrepreneurs.

Context: collaborative effort in CSCW research community
Purpose: provide actionable insights and foster positive change
Method: qualitative data collection mixed with quantitative analysis
Results: improved business models tailor to refugee needs
Ethical: respect participant privacy during data collection
Implications: potentially influence global policies and inclusive growth
